Summary I am an experienced Technician in the semiconductor industry with skills in operations, equipment, process and training. 
 
I have collected and evaluated operating data to conduct in-line equipment adjustments and ensure process optimization. I am a dependable technician that can get the job done. My experience ranges from preventive maintenance and troubleshooting, to spares and sustaining.  
 
In addition, I have been responsible for improvement processes that have helped my team be one of the top contributors across a 168 hour workforce. I have been responsible for containing nonstandard events in the production line which has saved the company time and money.  
 
As a trainer, I have trained several techs throughout my career which has allowed them to move within the company. I have been recognized for team leadership, ability to train, and instruct peers in manufacturing principles. 
 
I believe safety in the work place should be the number 1 priority. Not only is my own safety important but my team members safety is equally important. Losing one person on the team, due to a safety event, can have its disadvantages. We work to be able to do things we love; there is no sense in anyone getting hurt at work.  
 
I have a high degree of judgment in resolving complex nonstandard problems and developing recommendations with little to no supervision. I like to be a leader as well as work in a team environment.  
 
I enjoy meeting new people contact me if you would like to talk business or the outdoors.  
 
Specialties: material handling, basic knowledge in computers, problem solving, analysis, electrical, electromechanical, robotic (install, rebuild, calibration) optical sensors, motors, and vacuum systems. In addition, I have been responsible for improvement processes that have helped my team be one of the top contributors across a 168 hour workforce. I have been responsible for containing nonstandard events in the production line which has saved the company time and money.  
 
As a trainer, I have trained several techs throughout my career which has allowed them to move within the company. I have been recognized for team leadership, ability to train, and instruct peers in manufacturing principles. 
 
I believe safety in the work place should be the number 1 priority. Not only is my own safety important but my team members safety is equally important. Losing one person on the team, due to a safety event, can have its disadvantages. We work to be able to do things we love; there is no sense in anyone getting hurt at work.  
 
I have a high degree of judgment in resolving complex nonstandard problems and developing recommendations with little to no supervision. I like to be a leader as well as work in a team environment.  
 
I enjoy meeting new people contact me if you would like to talk business or the outdoors.  
 
Specialties: material handling, basic knowledge in computers, problem solving, analysis, electrical, electromechanical, robotic (install, rebuild, calibration) optical sensors, motors, and vacuum systems. Litho Ops/Maint Technician Intel Corporation August 2007  –  December 2013  (6 years 5 months) Aloha, OR Currently working as a Manufacturing Technician in the Lithography area on TEL ACT12 equipment. Manufacturing Technicians perform functions associated with all wafer production including operations, equipment work, process and training. Collects and evaluates operating data to conduct on-line equipment adjustment and ensure process optimization. Responsible for running lots in a qualitative way. Also, responsible for preventive maintenance, troubleshooting, spares, and sustaining. In addition, the Manufacturing Technician is responsible for improvement processes, troubleshooting nonstandard events in the production line, and reviewing technological health and stability. The Manufacturing Technician may be responsible for the buddy, trainer, and certifier levels and is in charge of updating training manuals. May participate in safety forums and Emergency Response Team as required. Work is somewhat complex and is performed within the spectrum ranging from narrowly defined parameters and limited judgment up to highly complex and nonstandard assignments in nature and broadly defined parameters. High degree of judgment and initiative is required in resolving complex nonstandard problems and developing recommendations. Normally receives general instructions on routine work, and detailed instructions on new work. Aviation Electronics Technician - Instructor United States Navy September 1992  –  December 1995  (3 years 4 months) Miramar, CA I taught 3 'major' courses in computerized automated electronic testing equipment for the following test benches: AN/USM-467 RADCOM, AN/USM-429 CAT IIID, and AN/USM-247 VAST (these were typically called ATE benches because they utilized pre-programmed software to perform the majority of the testing and diagnostic routines). These courses were called 'major courses' by the Navy because they taught a complete test bench system to students. The courses typically ran 10-13 weeks and Navy students were taught operations, diagnostics and troubleshooting, and repairs to many of the 'drawer' assemblies enclosed in the overall test bench. 
 
I also taught a 'minor' course for the HP 7906 disc drive system - this disc drive system was located in the RADCOM and CAT IIID test benches. This course focused on the testing/diagnosing, repair and replacement of end-user parts and, most importantly, calibration of the HP 7906 disc drive system to keep the test bench operational. RADCOM Operator/Maintainer United States Navy September 1988  –  September 1992  (4 years 1 month) Oak Harbor, WA I worked in an avionics shop in AIMD (Aviation Intermediate Maintenance Department) with the AN/USM-467 RADCOM test bench. I tested and repaired WRA and SRA components from both the A-6E Intruder bombing radar system and EA-6B Prowler ALQ-99 countermeasures radar set. After I returned from my second deployment aboard the USS Forrestal, I maintained my QA/CDI inspector certification within my shop. RADCOM Operator/Maintainer United States Navy January 1989  –  December 1991  (3 years) Mayport, FL Deployed aboard CV-59, USS Forrestal, in support of VAQ-142 on my first deployment and then VAQ-133 for my second deployment in the EA-6B Prowler vans (AIMD Dept, IM3 Division, Shop 10). On my second deployment, I was also selected to act as a QA inspector, working under the QA department as a Collateral Duty Inspector; I still worked as a technician on the RADCOM test bench, testing, diagnosing, and repairing WRAs (Weapons Replaceable Assemblies) and SRAs (Sub-Replaceable Assemblies) from the ALQ-99 Electronic Countermeasures system. 
 
My first deployment was in 1989-1990, and my second was in 1991 (this was the last operational deployment of the USS Forrestal) - both of these took place in the Mediterranean Ocean. •	General responsibilities included reverse engineering of sub-modules, parts review and inventory analysis, development and project management activities, and communication/coordination activities.

•	Communication and coordination activities included interdepartmental communications and coordination, timely reporting to appropriated groups, documentation, and scheduling as needed reports to management.
